diagrams.description: Ecological Restoration encompasses diverse ecosystems and approaches. Ecosystem types include forest restoration (reforestation, afforestation, native species planting, assisted natural regeneration), wetland restoration (hydrology re-establishment, native plant installation, invasive species removal, buffering), grassland and prairie restoration (native grass seeding, prescribed burning, grazing management), river and stream restoration (channel reconstruction, riparian buffer establishment, fish passage installation), coastal and marine restoration (mangrove planting, coral reef restoration, seagrass beds, salt marsh restoration), and mine reclamation (soil reconstruction, revegetation, acid mine drainage treatment). Restoration techniques feature passive restoration (natural regeneration, threat removal, protection), active intervention (soil amendment, native plantings, species reintroduction, structural additions like large woody debris), and assisted migration for climate adaptation. Key principles include reference ecosystems (historical conditions, nearby intact systems), ecological integrity (structure, composition, function), resilience (resistance to disturbance, recovery capacity), trajectory (succession pathways, alternative stable states), and adaptive management (monitoring, learning, adjusting). Assessment methods involve baseline surveys, biodiversity indices, ecosystem function metrics (nutrient cycling, carbon sequestration), remote sensing and GIS, and long-term monitoring plots. Challenges include invasive species control, climate change uncertainty, funding limitations, land tenure issues, and realistic goal-setting. Frameworks include Society for Ecological Restoration (SER) standards, UN Decade on Ecosystem Restoration (2021-2030), Bonn Challenge (forest restoration targets), and ecosystem services valuation. Benefits encompass biodiversity recovery, carbon sequestration, water quality improvement, flood mitigation, soil stabilization, and community wellbeing enhancement.
